<p><strong>General Motors’ January announcement </strong>that it would join other automakers by selling only zero-emission vehicles (in its case, by 2035) was one of the most well-publicized examples of something that has become crystal clear over the past few years: the momentum behind cleaner, software-enabled forms of mobility is powerful and seemingly unstoppable.</p>
<p>What does this mean for companies and consumers? In this article, we’ll look at four trends that illustrate the way this new form of transformation will develop: the increasing support of capital markets; the kinds of features these vehicles will have, as seen by the demands of Chinese consumers; the speed needed for this transition to contribute meaningfully to the slowing of climate change; and the impact this shift will have on labor markets.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge TableOfContents_mck-c-table-of-contents__zeYey"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h6 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-10 TableOfContents_mck-c-table-of-contents__heading__nQD1F">TABLE OF CONTENTS</h6><ol class="mdc-u-ts-7 TableOfContents_mck-c-table-of-contents__list__ivUca"><li class="TableOfContents_mck-c-table-of-contents__list-item__Q8xfB"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#section-header-1" class="mdc-c-link-heading___Zggl8_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Why capital markets love mobility</span></a></li><li class="TableOfContents_mck-c-table-of-contents__list-item__Q8xfB"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#section-header-2" class="mdc-c-link-heading___Zggl8_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">China’s connected consumer is the future</span></a></li><li class="TableOfContents_mck-c-table-of-contents__list-item__Q8xfB"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#section-header-3" class="mdc-c-link-heading___Zggl8_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Can electric vehicles put the brakes on climate change?</span></a></li><li class="TableOfContents_mck-c-table-of-contents__list-item__Q8xfB"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#section-header-4" class="mdc-c-link-heading___Zggl8_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">New mobility, new skills</span></a></li></ol></div></div></div></div></div>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-532E7FAB4EBF4AA6A6A740BE1065C796-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="Why capital markets love mobility" style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-1" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB" tabindex="-1"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Part 1</span></div><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>Why capital markets love mobility</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p><em>by <a href="/our-people/kersten-heineke">Kersten Heineke</a>, <a href="/our-people/timo-moller">Timo Möller</a>, <a href="/our-people/asutosh-padhi">Asutosh Padhi</a>, Dennis Schwedhelm, and <a href="/our-people/andreas-tschiesner">Andreas Tschiesner</a></em></p>
<p>Over the past year and a half, the mobility industry has significantly outperformed top-performing industries, such as semiconductors and big tech, in capital markets. We think this reflects that new mobility start-ups are doing six key things right:</p>
<!-- -->
<ol>
    <li><em>Accessing new value pools.</em> While public attention has focused on autonomous electric vehicles (EVs) that might replace today’s internal-combustion cars, the mobility industry has headed in several promising new directions. Shared mobility, for example, is an industry that could double in size by 2030. Advanced connectivity solutions for EVs, such as personalized contextual advertising based on driving routes, could create a considerable new subscription business, potentially generating up to $310 in revenue and $180 in cost savings per year per car by the end of this decade.</li>
    <li><em>Getting software right.</em> We estimate that the automotive software market will have grown by approximately 250 percent by the end of the decade. This will put software at the very center of new automobile designs.</li>
    <li><em>Winning the talent war.</em> New mobility requires new kinds of talent. New mobility players in the field are perceived as software- or electronics-first companies and have focused on hiring talent with digital skills from the outset. To catch up, traditional players will have to reskill up to a quarter of their current workforce.</li>
    <li><em>Focusing on green.</em> New mobility players have always seen the value of zero-emission vehicles and aim to cut both tailpipe emissions (which account for two-thirds of the total) and emissions from production (the remaining third). The €1.5 billion European Green Vehicles Initiative supports the effort. Consumers factoring sustainability into buying decisions helped drive EV sales up 43 percent in 2020.</li>
    <li><em>Focusing on customers.</em> Car buying and maintenance have entered the rapidly growing realm of experience shopping. New mobility players lead with a set of customer-centric solutions that ease the customer journey. It’s not just dedicated apps; there are also social networks, flagship showrooms, and lounges for vehicle owners, creating a pleasing environment that envelops consumers from sales to service upgrades.</li>
    <li><em>Offering new purchasing options.</em> Mobility start-ups are giving consumers what they want with the direct purchase of vehicles: 50 percent of consumers across the world’s key markets say they are interested in online car purchases, although less than 5 percent of purchases are made that way now. The absence of a traditional dealer structure allows new mobility players to save up to 25 percent (in dealer margins and incentives) on the price of each car. Traditional dealers see the handwriting on the wall: two-thirds expect that their OEMs will introduce direct sales channels by 2025.</li>
</ol>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/automotive%20and%20assembly/our%20insights/the%20irresistible%20momentum%20behind%20clean%20electric%20connected%20mobility%20four%20key%20trends/svgz-mckqmobility-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Capital market performance varies by industry cluster." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/automotive%20and%20assembly/our%20insights/the%20irresistible%20momentum%20behind%20clean%20electric%20connected%20mobility%20four%20key%20trends/svgz-mckqmobility-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Traditional auto companies will compete fiercely to capture a healthy portion of these new value pools. Hybrids and EVs have been part of their portfolios for a long time now, and they are rapidly accelerating their efforts to win subscription revenue and think software-first. Whether those efforts are enough for capital markets to reward them too remains an open question.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>About the author(s)</strong></p>
<p><strong><a href="/our-people/kersten-heineke">Kersten Heineke</a></strong> is a partner in McKinsey’s Frankfurt office, <strong><a href="/our-people/timo-moller">Timo Möller</a></strong> is a partner in the Cologne office, <strong><a href="/our-people/asutosh-padhi">Asutosh Padhi</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Chicago office, <strong>Dennis Schwedhelm</strong> is a senior expert, and <strong><a href="/our-people/andreas-tschiesner">Andreas Tschiesner</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Munich office.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-D2055B7AA1CE4A849FF73D026C37C7A2-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="China’s connected consumer is the future" style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-2" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB" tabindex="-1"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Part 2</span></div><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>China’s connected consumer is the future</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p><em>by <a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7bc806a505-40c1-4981-9b47-3f82031c0bf6%7d%40en">Paul Gao</a>, Florian Garms, <a href="/our-people/asad-husain">Asad Husain</a>, and <a href="/our-people/philipp-kampshoff">Philipp Kampshoff</a></em></p>
<p>If you’re a Chinese owner of an electric car, your experience is significantly different from that of most Western electric-car owners. In fact, your experience inside the car is in many ways just an extension of your experience outside the car.</p>
<p>New Chinese automakers have tapped into advanced technologies to deliver a customer journey that is friendly and convenient, starting with online sales, which are the norm in China. But the experience is truly differentiated when you climb into the driver’s seat. Advanced facial-recognition systems using in-vehicle cameras kick in immediately, adjusting the seat, steering wheel, and interior lighting to your preferred settings. A customized avatar on the central dashboard screen greets you and even offers up restaurant recommendations if you say that you’re looking for someplace to eat. If you want to change the music during your drive, just say so. Chinese automakers have also improved on charging and parking: valet charging services will drive the car to a charging station during your work hours and return it to your parking spot before your commute home. And if you do have to charge the car yourself, you can pay for it from the infotainment screen, which has many of the features and apps that you get on your smartphone.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/automotive%20and%20assembly/our%20insights/the%20irresistible%20momentum%20behind%20clean%20electric%20connected%20mobility%20four%20key%20trends/svgz-mckqmobility-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Connected cars have the power to woo consumers—especially in China." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/automotive%20and%20assembly/our%20insights/the%20irresistible%20momentum%20behind%20clean%20electric%20connected%20mobility%20four%20key%20trends/svgz-mckqmobility-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>These developments may not seem as significant as, say, electrification itself. But they have the potential to be hugely significant. Chinese consumers are willing to pay twice as much as their Western peers for such features. Electrification may eventually become the expected norm, just as gasoline-powered engines did. But connected, consumer-friendly features have the potential to woo customers—in China, 56 percent of consumers say they’d be willing to change brands for better connectivity. OEMs around the world would be wise to pay attention to that statistic. It may well be that the differentiating feature in the car of the future will be its ability to mimic the conveniences we’ve come to expect from our smartphones.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>About the author(s)</strong></p>
<p><strong><a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7bc806a505-40c1-4981-9b47-3f82031c0bf6%7d%40en">Paul Gao</a></strong> is a senior partner in McKinsey’s Hong Kong office, <strong>Florian Garms</strong> is a consultant in the Berlin office, <strong><a href="/our-people/asad-husain">Asad Husain</a></strong> is a partner in the Toronto office, and <strong><a href="/our-people/philipp-kampshoff">Philipp Kampshoff</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Houston office.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-8FCF003F707745AE90089EC2B6E87793-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="Can electric vehicles put the brakes on climate change?" style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-3" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB" tabindex="-1"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Part 3</span></div><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>Can electric vehicles put the brakes on climate change?</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p><em>by Julian Conzade, <a href="/our-people/russell-hensley">Russell Hensley</a>, and Patrick Schaufuss</em></p>
<p>Despite 2020 being a tipping-point year for EV sales, automakers and consumers will need to accelerate their adoption if we hope to meaningfully limit climate change. Reducing carbon emissions from vehicles is critical—currently, road transport accounts for 13 percent of global carbon emissions.</p>
<p>To understand the depth of the challenge, consider that the pace of technology development of mobility is already quite fast. The cost of EV batteries, for example, is now just $100 per kilowatt-hour, down from $1,200 in 2010. Investment in EV-related technologies and assets almost doubled in 2020. And yet these advancements still aren’t enough to ensure that we’ll hit the 1.5°C climate targets.</p>
<p>The decade between 2025 and 2035 will determine whether the industry can keep cumulative CO<sub>2</sub> emissions for passenger cars (through 2050) to under 45 gigatons, a “carbon budget” that would <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/climate-math-what-a-1-point-5-degree-pathway-would-take">help hold global temperature increases to under 1.5°C</a>, according to McKinsey analysis. Mobility players, consumers, and governments face five challenges:</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>Speed the shift to zero-emission vehicles.</em> This is the most efficient lever to reduce carbon emissions. By 2035, more than 95 percent of all cars and trucks on the road would need to be zero-emission vehicles to limit warming to 1.5°C.</li>
    <li><em>Leverage the abatement potential of transition technologies.</em> Hybrid vehicles and more efficient gas-powered cars can play an important role in the transition to a zero-emission global vehicle fleet.</li>
    <li><em>Reduce vehicle miles traveled.</em> While trends like increased hours of remote work may help reduce vehicular travel, governments may need to explore the traffic optimization potential of multimodal mobility.</li>
    <li><em>Increase share of renewables.</em> Clean electricity and low-carbon fuels (eg, renewable natural gas) are needed to reduce the life cycle emission of road transport.</li>
    <li><em>Zero-carbon supply chains.</em> OEMs will also turn their attention to supply chains. How can materials, their transport, and in-plant processes become carbon free? There are a number of promising efforts, like the development of “green” steel, and the location of battery plants close to OEMs to lower carbon transport costs. Some such plants are even powered with carbon-free, water-generated electricity.</li>
</ol>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/automotive%20and%20assembly/our%20insights/the%20irresistible%20momentum%20behind%20clean%20electric%20connected%20mobility%20four%20key%20trends/svgz-mckqmobility-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Mobility players’ efforts can cut carbon emissions and help keep the global temperature increase under 1.5°C." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/automotive%20and%20assembly/our%20insights/the%20irresistible%20momentum%20behind%20clean%20electric%20connected%20mobility%20four%20key%20trends/svgz-mckqmobility-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>None of this will be easy. Holding emissions under the 45 gigaton target will require a cross-industry effort among companies, industries, and government. For instance, the energy and transport sectors can work together to drive smart-charging technologies that would in turn accelerate the shift to EVs. Coalitions can be formed to develop clean supply chains for the creation of low-carbon battery solutions that reflect the full potential of a circular economy. Ultimately, regulators and policy makers may have to intercede, adopting an ecosystem perspective with cross-border goals and meaningful timelines for everything from number of charge points needed to the trajectory of carbon reduction. Without this kind of cooperation, it’s unlikely that the shift to EVs will realize its full potential for creating a sustainable battery value chain and for mitigating the impact of climate change.</p>

<p><strong>About the author(s)</strong></p>
<p><strong>Julian Conzade</strong> is a consultant in McKinsey’s Munich office, where <strong>Patrick Schaufuss</strong> is a partner; <strong><a href="/our-people/russell-hensley">Russell Hensley</a></strong> is a partner in the Detroit office.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-ADCF0776BC8E4B39B932DCD14C21C089-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="New mobility, new skills" style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-4" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB" tabindex="-1"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Part 4</span></div><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>New mobility, new skills</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p><em>by <a href="/our-people/bjorn-hagemann">Björn Hagemann</a>, <a href="/our-people/ruth-heuss">Ruth Heuss</a>, and Kirsten Weerda</em></p>
<p>Over the next five to ten years, the skill sets of traditional automakers and suppliers will need to shift dramatically. Several factors will drive this change.</p>
<p>The rising importance of in-vehicle software and connected and autonomous cars increases the need for digital talent, putting OEMs worldwide in direct competition with Silicon Valley and the Chinese digital giants. But the shift isn’t merely an issue of seeking out new kinds of engineers. Drawing from thousands of existing databases, we created a taxonomy of the future skills the industry will need. Based on that work, we believe that demand for workers with today’s standard skill sets will drop by up to 30 percent in the coming decade.</p>
<p>A reduction of employees could occur across the entire automotive value chain. As consumers become increasingly comfortable buying everything online, existing dealer networks could shrink dramatically and shift their focus to maintenance. Manufacturing could take a similar hit, driven mostly by OEMs shifting to EVs with simpler assembly processes and very different parts. Both factory workers and current powertrain suppliers will be affected. Existing large-scale combustion-engineering departments will no longer be needed after 2030—EVs require engineers with more electrical skills and an understanding of battery chemistry. As with many other industries, up to 50 percent of some support-function tasks, such as accounting or order processing, are likely to be fully automated. And for those tasks that can’t be automated, we may see the creation of shared service centers in low-cost locations, now that companies are more skilled at using digital tools and more comfortable with remote work because of the pandemic.</p>
<p>New skills will be needed, especially in software and data analytics, which will be critical for online sales and marketing channels. We believe automakers can close up to half of the skills gap organically, by way of reskilling, continuous education, and hiring. M&A and strategic partnerships, already a core aspect of the mobility ecosystem, will also play a big role. Every automaker needs a strategic workforce plan that identifies critical roles and skills at every level in the organization, and matches the right talent to the most value-creating roles. This would be a big shift from the traditional succession and talent management processes of OEMs, which have focused on the top tiers of the company.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/automotive%20and%20assembly/our%20insights/the%20irresistible%20momentum%20behind%20clean%20electric%20connected%20mobility%20four%20key%20trends/svgz-mckqmobility-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Today’s automotive workforce will need to reskill to prepare for the future of connected, electric mobility." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/automotive%20and%20assembly/our%20insights/the%20irresistible%20momentum%20behind%20clean%20electric%20connected%20mobility%20four%20key%20trends/svgz-mckqmobility-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>This skills transformation will demand a culture transformation as well. Automakers will have to provide the kind of employee experience that top talent has come to expect at tech companies, which means approachable managers, speedy hiring and onboarding, agile-work and fast-decision processes using QBRs [quarterly business reviews] and OKRs [objectives and key results] methodologies, compensation and incentives tied to talent rather than hierarchy, and an acceptance of flexible and remote work. All in all, the changes to the automotive workforce are likely to be as extensive as the changes coming to the vehicles they manufacture.</p>

id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"The irresistible momentum behind clean electric connected mobility mobility"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Mobility’s future is visible in the increasing support of capital markets, the demands of Chinese consumers, the effort to slow climate change, and the new skills automakers will need to deal with these shifts."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-04-06T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGeneral Motors\u0026rsquo; January announcement \u003c/strong\u003ethat it would join other automakers by selling only zero-emission vehicles (in its case, by 2035) was one of the most well-publicized examples of something that has become crystal clear over the past few years: the momentum behind cleaner, software-enabled forms of mobility is powerful and seemingly unstoppable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat does this mean for companies and consumers? In this article, we\u0026rsquo;ll look at four trends that illustrate the way this new form of transformation will develop: the increasing support of capital markets; the kinds of features these vehicles will have, as seen by the demands of Chinese consumers; the speed needed for this transition to contribute meaningfully to the slowing of climate change; and the impact this shift will have on labor markets.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[TableOfContents]]\n[[SectionHeader 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eby \u003ca href=\"/our-people/kersten-heineke\"\u003eKersten Heineke\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/our-people/timo-moller\"\u003eTimo M\u0026ouml;ller\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/our-people/asutosh-padhi\"\u003eAsutosh Padhi\u003c/a\u003e, Dennis Schwedhelm, and \u003ca href=\"/our-people/andreas-tschiesner\"\u003eAndreas Tschiesner\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOver the past year and a half, the mobility industry has significantly outperformed top-performing industries, such as semiconductors and big tech, in capital markets. We think this reflects that new mobility start-ups are doing six key things right:\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAccessing new value pools.\u003c/em\u003e While public attention has focused on autonomous electric vehicles (EVs) that might replace today\u0026rsquo;s internal-combustion cars, the mobility industry has headed in several promising new directions. Shared mobility, for example, is an industry that could double in size by 2030. Advanced connectivity solutions for EVs, such as personalized contextual advertising based on driving routes, could create a considerable new subscription business, potentially generating up to $310 in revenue and $180 in cost savings per year per car by the end of this decade.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGetting software right.\u003c/em\u003e We estimate that the automotive software market will have grown by approximately 250 percent by the end of the decade. This will put software at the very center of new automobile designs.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWinning the talent war.\u003c/em\u003e New mobility requires new kinds of talent. New mobility players in the field are perceived as software- or electronics-first companies and have focused on hiring talent with digital skills from the outset. To catch up, traditional players will have to reskill up to a quarter of their current workforce.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFocusing on green.\u003c/em\u003e New mobility players have always seen the value of zero-emission vehicles and aim to cut both tailpipe emissions (which account for two-thirds of the total) and emissions from production (the remaining third). The \u0026euro;1.5 billion European Green Vehicles Initiative supports the effort. Consumers factoring sustainability into buying decisions helped drive EV sales up 43 percent in 2020.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFocusing on customers.\u003c/em\u003e Car buying and maintenance have entered the rapidly growing realm of experience shopping. New mobility players lead with a set of customer-centric solutions that ease the customer journey. It\u0026rsquo;s not just dedicated apps; there are also social networks, flagship showrooms, and lounges for vehicle owners, creating a pleasing environment that envelops consumers from sales to service upgrades.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eOffering new purchasing options.\u003c/em\u003e Mobility start-ups are giving consumers what they want with the direct purchase of vehicles: 50 percent of consumers across the world\u0026rsquo;s key markets say they are interested in online car purchases, although less than 5 percent of purchases are made that way now. The absence of a traditional dealer structure allows new mobility players to save up to 25 percent (in dealer margins and incentives) on the price of each car. Traditional dealers see the handwriting on the wall: two-thirds expect that their OEMs will introduce direct sales channels by 2025.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eTraditional auto companies will compete fiercely to capture a healthy portion of these new value pools. Hybrids and EVs have been part of their portfolios for a long time now, and they are rapidly accelerating their efforts to win subscription revenue and think software-first. Whether those efforts are enough for capital markets to reward them too remains an open question.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAbout the author(s)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/kersten-heineke\"\u003eKersten Heineke\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Frankfurt office, \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/timo-moller\"\u003eTimo M\u0026ouml;ller\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in the Cologne office, \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/asutosh-padhi\"\u003eAsutosh Padhi\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior partner in the Chicago office, \u003cstrong\u003eDennis Schwedhelm\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior expert, and \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/andreas-tschiesner\"\u003eAndreas Tschiesner\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior partner in the Munich office.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 2]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eby \u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7bc806a505-40c1-4981-9b47-3f82031c0bf6%7d%40en\"\u003ePaul Gao\u003c/a\u003e, Florian Garms, \u003ca href=\"/our-people/asad-husain\"\u003eAsad Husain\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"/our-people/philipp-kampshoff\"\u003ePhilipp Kampshoff\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you\u0026rsquo;re a Chinese owner of an electric car, your experience is significantly different from that of most Western electric-car owners. In fact, your experience inside the car is in many ways just an extension of your experience outside the car.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNew Chinese automakers have tapped into advanced technologies to deliver a customer journey that is friendly and convenient, starting with online sales, which are the norm in China. But the experience is truly differentiated when you climb into the driver\u0026rsquo;s seat. Advanced facial-recognition systems using in-vehicle cameras kick in immediately, adjusting the seat, steering wheel, and interior lighting to your preferred settings. A customized avatar on the central dashboard screen greets you and even offers up restaurant recommendations if you say that you\u0026rsquo;re looking for someplace to eat. If you want to change the music during your drive, just say so. Chinese automakers have also improved on charging and parking: valet charging services will drive the car to a charging station during your work hours and return it to your parking spot before your commute home. And if you do have to charge the car yourself, you can pay for it from the infotainment screen, which has many of the features and apps that you get on your smartphone.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThese developments may not seem as significant as, say, electrification itself. But they have the potential to be hugely significant. Chinese consumers are willing to pay twice as much as their Western peers for such features. Electrification may eventually become the expected norm, just as gasoline-powered engines did. But connected, consumer-friendly features have the potential to woo customers\u0026mdash;in China, 56 percent of consumers say they\u0026rsquo;d be willing to change brands for better connectivity. OEMs around the world would be wise to pay attention to that statistic. It may well be that the differentiating feature in the car of the future will be its ability to mimic the conveniences we\u0026rsquo;ve come to expect from our smartphones.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAbout the author(s)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7bc806a505-40c1-4981-9b47-3f82031c0bf6%7d%40en\"\u003ePaul Gao\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior partner in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Hong Kong office, \u003cstrong\u003eFlorian Garms\u003c/strong\u003e is a consultant in the Berlin office, \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/asad-husain\"\u003eAsad Husain\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in the Toronto office, and \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/philipp-kampshoff\"\u003ePhilipp Kampshoff\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior partner in the Houston office.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 3]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eby Julian Conzade, \u003ca href=\"/our-people/russell-hensley\"\u003eRussell Hensley\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026nbsp;and Patrick Schaufuss\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite 2020 being a tipping-point year for EV sales, automakers and consumers will need to accelerate their adoption if we hope to meaningfully limit climate change. Reducing carbon emissions from vehicles is critical\u0026mdash;currently, road transport accounts for 13 percent of global carbon emissions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo understand the depth of the challenge, consider that the pace of technology development of mobility is already quite fast. The cost of EV batteries, for example, is now just $100 per kilowatt-hour, down from $1,200 in 2010. Investment in EV-related technologies and assets almost doubled in 2020. And yet these advancements still aren\u0026rsquo;t enough to ensure that we\u0026rsquo;ll hit the 1.5\u0026deg;C climate targets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe decade between 2025 and 2035 will determine whether the industry can keep cumulative CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emissions for passenger cars (through 2050) to under 45 gigatons, a \u0026ldquo;carbon budget\u0026rdquo; that would \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/climate-math-what-a-1-point-5-degree-pathway-would-take\"\u003ehelp hold global temperature increases to under 1.5\u0026deg;C\u003c/a\u003e, according to McKinsey analysis. Mobility players, consumers, and governments face five challenges:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSpeed the shift to zero-emission vehicles.\u003c/em\u003e This is the most efficient lever to reduce carbon emissions. By 2035, more than 95 percent of all cars and trucks on the road would need to be zero-emission vehicles to limit warming to 1.5\u0026deg;C.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLeverage the abatement potential of transition technologies.\u003c/em\u003e Hybrid vehicles and more efficient gas-powered cars can play an important role in the transition to a zero-emission global vehicle fleet.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eReduce vehicle miles traveled.\u003c/em\u003e While trends like increased hours of remote work may help reduce vehicular travel, governments may need to explore the traffic optimization potential of multimodal mobility.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIncrease share of renewables.\u003c/em\u003e Clean electricity and low-carbon fuels (eg, renewable natural gas) are needed to reduce the life cycle emission of road transport.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eZero-carbon supply chains.\u003c/em\u003e OEMs will also turn their attention to supply chains. How can materials, their transport, and in-plant processes become carbon free? There are a number of promising efforts, like the development of \u0026ldquo;green\u0026rdquo; steel, and the location of battery plants close to OEMs to lower carbon transport costs. Some such plants are even powered with carbon-free, water-generated electricity.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eNone of this will be easy. Holding emissions under the 45 gigaton target will require a cross-industry effort among companies, industries, and government. For instance, the energy and transport sectors can work together to drive smart-charging technologies that would in turn accelerate the shift to EVs. Coalitions can be formed to develop clean supply chains for the creation of low-carbon battery solutions that reflect the full potential of a circular economy. Ultimately, regulators and policy makers may have to intercede, adopting an ecosystem perspective with cross-border goals and meaningful timelines for everything from number of charge points needed to the trajectory of carbon reduction. Without this kind of cooperation, it\u0026rsquo;s unlikely that the shift to EVs will realize its full potential for creating a sustainable battery value chain and for mitigating the impact of climate change.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAbout the author(s)\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJulian Conzade\u003c/strong\u003e is a consultant in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Munich office, where \u003cstrong\u003ePatrick Schaufuss\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner; \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/russell-hensley\"\u003eRussell Hensley\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in the Detroit office.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 4]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eby \u003ca href=\"/our-people/bjorn-hagemann\"\u003eBj\u0026ouml;rn Hagemann\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/our-people/ruth-heuss\"\u003eRuth Heuss\u003c/a\u003e, and Kirsten Weerda\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOver the next five to ten years, the skill sets of traditional automakers and suppliers will need to shift dramatically. Several factors will drive this change.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe rising importance of in-vehicle software and connected and autonomous cars increases the need for digital talent, putting OEMs worldwide in direct competition with Silicon Valley and the Chinese digital giants. But the shift isn\u0026rsquo;t merely an issue of seeking out new kinds of engineers. Drawing from thousands of existing databases, we created a taxonomy of the future skills the industry will need. Based on that work, we believe that demand for workers with today\u0026rsquo;s standard skill sets will drop by up to 30 percent in the coming decade.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA reduction of employees could occur across the entire automotive value chain. As consumers become increasingly comfortable buying everything online, existing dealer networks could shrink dramatically and shift their focus to maintenance. Manufacturing could take a similar hit, driven mostly by OEMs shifting to EVs with simpler assembly processes and very different parts. Both factory workers and current powertrain suppliers will be affected. Existing large-scale combustion-engineering departments will no longer be needed after 2030\u0026mdash;EVs require engineers with more electrical skills and an understanding of battery chemistry. As with many other industries, up to 50 percent of some support-function tasks, such as accounting or order processing, are likely to be fully automated. And for those tasks that can\u0026rsquo;t be automated, we may see the creation of shared service centers in low-cost locations, now that companies are more skilled at using digital tools and more comfortable with remote work because of the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNew skills will be needed, especially in software and data analytics, which will be critical for online sales and marketing channels. We believe automakers can close up to half of the skills gap organically, by way of reskilling, continuous education, and hiring. M\u0026amp;A and strategic partnerships, already a core aspect of the mobility ecosystem, will also play a big role. Every automaker needs a strategic workforce plan that identifies critical roles and skills at every level in the organization, and matches the right talent to the most value-creating roles. This would be a big shift from the traditional succession and talent management processes of OEMs, which have focused on the top tiers of the company.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eThis skills transformation will demand a culture transformation as well. Automakers will have to provide the kind of employee experience that top talent has come to expect at tech companies, which means approachable managers, speedy hiring and onboarding, agile-work and fast-decision processes using QBRs [quarterly business reviews] and OKRs [objectives and key results] methodologies, compensation and incentives tied to talent rather than hierarchy, and an acceptance of flexible and remote work. All in all, the changes to the automotive workforce are likely to be as extensive as the changes coming to the vehicles they manufacture.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr
